bar and chain come loose in box. in trying to assemble, the c-clip and flat washer holding the drive sprocket came off. tried to put back but c-clip/snap ring has no spring to it and was stretched. that's why it came off in the first place. will buy new one tomorrow and report back.installed new c-clip and assembled saw. turned on saw and chain jumped off. opened case and found new c-clip had jumped off. looked closely at motor shaft and found groove shallow and rounded. will not hold c-clip. returning unit.see my photo on product page.

Not sure how humane it is to electrocute a mouse, but this thing reminds me of a terminator that came back in time to kill Sarah Connor -- it won't stop until it's target is dead. Well, or at least until the batteries run out.I truly had to chuckle at this thing -- it literally turns mouse catching into an automated process -- mouse steps in -- ZAP! -- then the electrocution chamber rotates, drops the mouse in a compartment, and rotates back into position, ready for its next victim.  A light even turns on when the "drawer" is full -- just pull it out, dispose of the rodents and slide the drawer back in for the next pile of vermin.  I'm not sure who needs a mouse trap that's this efficient and has such a large capacity.  If you have that many mice, it may be time to move!  For my purposes, I put it in the garage, and it did catch the one mouse we had. (Hopefully the only one.)Overall, I think it's pretty good at what it does and is about as "humane" as any other trap.  It's not like any of them safely capture mice so they can be set free in the wild.  Like all mouse traps, it's basically a killing machine.  But at least this one can be reused again and again, and emptied with little fuss or creepy-crawly feelings!  I agree, however, that this may cost a lot in batteries.  But I actually prefer battery operated, over plugging it into a wall outlet.  If you have mice, the trap needs to go where the mice are, not where the nearest outlet happens to be.  It certainly beats those old style traps that always snap my fingers!UPDATE 7/18/11 - Good News/Bad News --- this thing just caught another mouse; which means we have more mice than i thought. Eeeeeeew!

reviewText: This part fits very well and is easy to install. In my case, the gas tank did not need to be removed; I just removed the bottom two screws from the starter and it slipped out. The top two screws are just locators. The warning is for the plastic cap, or dust cover. It does not snap over the flange like the original, so I superglued it like others had suggested. Unfortunately, it fell off after one use and got wedged against the flywheel, locking up the engine so it wouldn't start with either the pull or electric starter. Had to remove the pull starter and fish out the cap by hand to loosen it up.I'm going to look into the Ariens cap that was mentioned in another review, but for now I've left the cap off and I'd recommend others do the same.

reviewText: I compost, recycle, reduce, reuse, buy recycled products, use flourescent bulbs and will be trying to install solar panels soon. Not a granola, just trying to be responsible about my life. So, the next logical step in my garden would be to stop using sevin dust and use an ecologoically responsible pesticide. Well, I am going back to sevin dust. My beautiful garden was destroyed overnight. My hubby sprayed this "pesticide" to my corn, squash, sweet potatoes, watermelon, and pumpkins. Woke up this morning and my corns are laying on the ground. No rain last night, so they were not blown over. Went to take a look and the corn has yellow stalks right from the middle down. Exactly where the insecticide instructed us to spray. The pumpkins have splashes of yellow where the insecticide landed on the leaves, the squash leaves are laying flat on the ground instead of springing gaily from the stalks witht he same yellow splashes. The last 6 weeks of work was for naught. Will be contacting the company and banging my head on a corporate beauracy for naught also. BTW, found a beautiful, healthy caterpillar laying next to a corn stalk. Looks like something survived...

I bought this after trying other brands for Budworm on my petunias.  I had sprayed numerous times with the recommended product that they use in my area for these pests, with no visible effects.  After a month of no relief from these destructive pests, I googled Budworm and came up with a video of a nurseryman from the Portland area with rave reviews and with a eco friendly, pet friendly stamp for Deadbug Brew, so out of desperation, I ordered it.  After the first spraying of the product, my petunias started to bloom again within  days.  Within 1 1/2 weeks, they were totally covered in blooms again.  I saw some signs of the budworm again after another week in just a small area, so I sprayed again.  I have eliminated the little monsters, so I am a firm believer in this product.  The product came sealed in plastic, so that if the product had leaked during shipment, it would have been contained, but all arrived in tact.  Hooray for Deadbug Brew!

reviewText: GREAT SPRAYER: Worked right out of the gate, no problems, this is the third sprayer I have purchased the best.

We have a 4 acre lot that was originally a potato field.  We have worked long hours to turn that into a nice lawn area.  We still had some patches that were rough and needed a roller to help smooth that out.  This product worked great, easily pulls behind the 4-wheeler and when empty is very light and easy to store.

No Bells and Whistles here. No fancy colors. Just pure performance. Similar products at the local hardware stores cost almost twice as much. I am not sure why amazon is selling this for less than twenty dollars.This is my third Corona product - I'm impressed with the other two (shears and pruner) and this lopper impressed me yet again. It has a mighty long handle and a mechanism to further increase power at the blade - what Corona calls a "power bearing". One can now cut tall branches and even thick branches with ease. Granted that my tool is still new, but the cutting performance was almost like slicing through butter. My other two Corona tools have kept up their sharp edge quite well after a few months of moderate use.The aluminum handle also keeps the lopper light making for fatigue free handling. I'm glad I bought this..Only con is - must be kept away from children - or they will be slicing their fingers or worse. This tool needs a locking mechanism.
summary: Yet another Corona product that is well made and functional

When rats and mice first showed up in our house, our efforts to get rid of them started right away.  First we tried the rat baits and glue traps.  Rat baits killed one mouse and the others eluded the glue traps.  Then we tried the tried and true bait leading to a trash can setup and nothing happened. After a while of failed attempts, I brought the Rat Zapper.  I followed the instructions and nothing for a week or so.  So we moved it around every couple of days and kept on changing the bait in the Rat Zapper.  Then finally we got our second and unexpected third rat on back to back days. Amazingly they went for a combination of onions, potatoes chips, and dried dog food. Yes, this thing actually works and works well.  You may have to keep moving it around a bit to possible spots but eventually you'll get your little vermin(s).

For the past four years we've been experiencing some problems with deer in our neighborhood and have been frustrated to come outside on spring and summer mornings to find raspberry plants eaten, ash and vine maple trees nibbled down to nothing and geraniums eaten as soon as they bloom.  My husband did some research and read about the Bobbex spray so we decided to order a bottle to try.  It is definitely working, but the smell for the first 24 hours is truly disgusting.  The trees are still intact though, so it seems great overall.  One issue that we've found on the vine maples is that the leaves seem to be a bit disfigured after using the spray three times.  We obviously do not use this on our raspberries, but two of the water scarecrows seem to be doing the trick for that issue.
summary: Works, but stinks to high heaven!

NickinDallas hit it on the head with his review. I had the identical experience.  The product looks promising with its flowered metal design, swiveling arm, and attractive antique bronze finish. After mounting it to a brick wall with my own mortar/concrete screws, I am hopeful the swivel arm will hold the weight of 100' of 5/8-inch rather heavy rubber hose, although I am not confident. As in the video provided by NickinDallas, the plastic POS clip which is supposed secure the water input spigot to the hose reel did not even hold while removing the hose reel from its packaging. When turning on the water for the first time after installation, the spigot immediately popped off the hose reel spraying water everywhere. The clip is necessary to secure the spigot, and I will try wiring it into position as another reviewer mentioned until I find time to make some sort of replacement piece. But for the money this product cost, why should I have to spend my time fixing it?!
summary: Promising Design Ruined by Inferior Chinese Manufacturing

Put them on the grill when you light it, and they'll be ready when the grill is ready.I've had these for years and the wooden handles are a smidge loose, but they work fine. I did not have a good experience with IPI. The quick-connect fitting provided to connect the cap to the gas tank did not seal and quickly dumped pint of fuel on the floor when I disconnected the tank to reposition the generator. I contacted Acme Electric Motor, Inc. the vendor who sold the product to me and was informed that they had no warranty responsibility and gave me IPI’s phone number to request help. I called IPI's phone - busy, so I went to the IPI website and filled out customer support form online submitted it but did not receive any confirmation that my support request was received. I waited a few days more and then tried the phone number again. This time a fellow picked up right away. I told him my problem, he assured me he would correct the problem and would send me a replacement quick-connect fitting right away. I'm still waiting. My advice is don't buy IPI's Berg system. Even though it seems to be a simple system, the company does not seem to have a working quality control system in place. And of course the potential for a serious accidental fire makes this product a very bad choice. My advice, don’t open it, send it back ASAP.
summary: Poor Quality and non-existant customer service

This tape sticks to ITSELF much better than to copper pipe. The amount was ample for 15 feet of heat tape (I know it is confusing, but the heat tape is the black plastic covered heating element that this tape I am reviewing positions against the pipe to be heated). I applied it every six inches (sometimes 4 inches on pipe curves) and even had some left over.This tape has a backing. This paper backing must be removed prior to applying the tape to the pipe. This can be tricky in a crawl space because you have to pull each tape section (precutting sections makes applying easier and can be done before you get in the crawl space) off the backing and then apply it to the pipe and heat tape with the heat tape firmly against the pipe. It's impossible to do that with gloves on (you need the gloves for the insulation application later on). Make sure you circle the tape over itself to make sure it won't lose it's grip.Remember, the tape is the device that keeps your electrical element (heat tape) up against the pipe! If your heat tape has large gaps where it isn't touching properly, you will use more elctricity because it will take longer for the pipe to get to 45 degrees and the heat tape will wear out sooner because it's on more often. Don't skimp on applying this tape!Finally, do some math on the length of your pipe and how many strips of tape to precut BEFORE you get in the crawl space. Take the tape sections and the rest of the tape and some scissors in a small plastic bag with you. Everything you can do before you get in there helps.I'm 65 and was still sore for about three days after the job despite a lot of preplanning.

I can't think of anything I don't like about this yard tool.  I have a yard full of dandelions, and I had been using a small hand tool, which worked pretty well, but required that I either stoop or kneel, and if it was a plant with deep roots, it took some exertion, which I try to avoid, as I have a rib cage injury.  I read the product information, then many of the customer reviews, and I easily decided that this item was worth a try.  Honestly, I am so glad that I did, because it has made my life so much easier.  Most of the time, I can center it on the flowers the first time, then stepping on the peddle/lever closest to the blades, the blades will sink into the dirt quite easily.  It doesn't take much force, and you'll be able to feel that the blades have gone all the way into the dirt, and then you can immediately pull up on the handle, sliding your foot down to the end of the peddle/lever as you do so, and it's out, usually roots and all!  If you go off-center, you can usually repeat the process and extract the remainder.  It's actually kind of fun for a while, and the only time I have a problem, is when the dandelions grow in a cluster, then it sometimes takes me a little longer to judge their centers, but that's not the fault of the tool.  Because I'm using my hands, with the aid of my foot on the pedal/lever, there's kind of a pivot action going on, which eliminates all resistance on the part of the plant, so there is no exertion on my part, and nothing to bother my injury.  I would highly recommend this product.

Instructions are 1 page with a couple of photos, leaves a lot to be disired.studied them for a hour or 2 looking at the parts, assembleb the end piece'sand sliped them on the shaff, then looked at the 2 collars on the shaft, they are put on in the factory, backwards, there is a grove in them to slip over the bearing that has the grove pointing out wards it takes a 1/8 allen wrench,  lossen them but could not move them by hand, had to tap them with a small hammer, turns out after I got them off the allen heads set screw indented the steel roller axle, had to take a file and grind these marks off before i could move the colars, then it had the left side bracket that is bolted on 3 3/8 and the right 3 5/8, I used one pair chanel locks to hold them moving them until they were square, this was the easy part, got them square and drilled them, I made the mistake of locking those collars, leave them loose until you bolt the left and right brackets in place, made the mistake of putting the bolts down where I bored the holes, had to change them later, couldn't get the outer brackets in because the ones that had to have holes bored for interfered by sticking down in the way so put the bolts in from the bottom nuts on top. so you can get the bolts that go thru the side brackets side ways,you can slide those locking collars all the way in and still put the roller on, and the roller will move back and forth to line up even on both sides .the right hand bracket is really tuff, the deck roller is right in the way, I should have taken this off, it would have been a lot eaiser, they say it would be easier to take the rear wheels off,, you can't judge how high to set the left and right brackets because if you set the deck for 3 1/2 inchs them if you take the wheels off you better not have the mower jacked up more than a 1/4 higher than it set with deck from the ground.  take that right side deck wheel off, will be a lot eaisersum it up, put the bearings in the side brackets, move the whole assembly in place and line up one side bracket mark it how high the side bracket is on the support bracket, slide the roller out and put the side you maked on and then the other using the same height, now you can slide the roller and move it back and forth to make even in the bearings then lock the 2 sliding collars in place and lock them down, when its right the roller axle is all I planted all of the seeds in the packet in one tray, applied heat from below with a seed germination mat, and covered the flat with a plastic lid. Five seeds germinated and two of those did not root. I have a flat with three plants and the rest of the pods are empty. I seeded approximately two to four seeds per pod so edge effects and inter-pod differences in climate control are very unlikely since not one pod germinated more than one seed. I.E. if it were a climate control problem any pod that produced 1 germinated seed should have seen germination from every seed in that pod. This was not the case. I had two germinated at pods on the edge of the flat and three in the middle of the flat. Two of the middle plants did not root.I did not check to see if there was PLS (pure live seed) test results on the product description. I won't purchase seed without a PLS test again.

This grill I installed on my hot dog cart so that I could shift our business to backyard barbecues.First off the issue that I had that may not be an issue at all to others. It came with 3 grills and a griddle. I did not need the griddle because I needed more grilling surface. To change it over to be all grills cost me over a hundred dollars. There are only a few sites that sell the accessories for this grill and it took me about a week to find the grill and the diffuser that goes under the grill plate.Now for grilling. This grill is so impressive. It cooks evenly and thoroughly. I did 3 events this summer each with over a hundred or more pounds per event all cooked on this grill. It never skipped a beat. It is large enough to place about 25 or so chicken breasts on at once. The cover is solid and balanced so that opening and closing is easy. Also efficient, I cooked for hours at a time I would say maybe 15 hours or so with it on full or medium the whole time and I only went through 1 tank.Pros:+ Great quality construction+ Comes with Natural Gas conversion for free for using it in your home (deck).+ Efficient+ Cooks evenly and thoroughly+ Easy to cleanCons:- Comes with one section being a griddle which is fine but it does not come with a diffuser under that griddle so you need to purchase another.- Lost a knob a day after I purchased (probably my fault but double check them)Overall this was a great capital expense for my business and should make you a nice backyard BBQ grill or even use it as a built in.Thanks for reading my review.-
summary: This this is a beast of a grill.

I have the 13KW unit that is sold by Lowe's home centers but is still a Generac. It came with the switch, leads and pad. Mine Is setup for natural gas. It is close ( 3 ft or so) behind our house as code required. The unit is now 2 years young and works great. Sure you can hear it running but it is not that bad, especially since it comes on seconds after a power failure. No more house full of flashlights and extra batteries or having food go bad. It is large enough to handle our Ac unit. We've had about 7 or 8 times where it ran for at least a few hours and once for 3 days.Maintenance is easy since the oil filter and drain are easily accessible. My only wish would be for hydraulic tappets since the solid ones that it uses must be adjusted. The front is easily accessible while the rear is a bit of a stretch. All in all a few hours work at a lazy pace.I also purchased extra main fuses for the main switch panel (yes cartridge fuses) and also for the single auto type fuse on the outside unit - but I have never had one gone bad. They are just more peace of mind.Lastly I will talk about Generac service. It came with the side door lock jammed, one phone call and the new one was here in a few days. I have since called them a few times with questions, mostly about maintenance and they were always professional. If my next house needs an emergency generator then I WILL buy a Generac unit.

I've been using this product for years. Yes, it does help in killing and controlling termite infestations. This is only a tool to kill and control the termites outside within the grounds around your home. You will also need to kill the nests within any wood structures as necessary...I recommendOrtho Home Defense Termite & Destructive Bug Killer - 32 oz. 0194260to treat and kill colonies in walls, floors and window frames. Look for toothpick sized holes dispersing wood particles. You may have to drill the hole larger and saturate with termite killer. I use a garden pump-sprayer with termite killer mixture and spray directly in the termite holes. Holes should be filled with caulking or re-plastered & re-painted to seal in termite killer. The killer should remain effective for years.I have a small apartment complex that had a serious termite infestation. I initially hired a professional which eliminated some termites but the infestation arose again the next year. When I called back for warranty re-treating, the professional did re-treat the areas originally treated but stated any other areas are new colonies and not covered by the warranty. Rather than spend hundreds more for a new treatment, I chose to educate myself on the life of the (btw blind) termite.Termites can live 25 years and must start a nest with two asexual termites. One becomes the male and one becomes the female queen. They reproduce drones with one purpose, to feed their queen. She remains stationary within the nest and can become 25 times larger in size...a real fat mama! If her male partner should die, one of the drones gets the privilege to be her new sexual boy-toy.Anyway, I learned subterranean termites need moisture to live and reproduce. These termites feed on plant/tree roots and then swarm (usually in seasonal hot weather) outside the ground and travel to nearby wood structures to form nests. These are the termites that destroy your home. These are the colonies that, most importantly, need to be controlled and killed.If you get the picture, the termite stakes are used to control and kill the subterranean termites outside your home and the spray mixture is used to control and kill the nests within wood.When I first used these stakes about 10 years ago, there was no "pop-up" indicator. I just know these were working since the swarms dissipated. These stakes last about a year killing termites unless there is an excessive amount of water washing away the chemical. Still, within the ground, the chemical helps kill termites. It did take me two (15) stake treatments in the course of 18 months to get the subterranean termites under control and several spray treatments in the various apartments and wood structures around the complex to get control of the termites. Now, I just watch for any new nests and treat accordingly.In closing, this product works to help kill and control termites.
summary: Subterranean Termite Killer...Helps to Kill/Control Termites & Ants

I got a pair of these for the New England Tough Mudder (6 MAY 2012). I trained with them all winter, in and out of cold water, carrying crud, in the mud, climbing ropes, etc. They have a GREAT grip (when dry). When these things get wet, grabbing onto metallic objects will be more slippery than going bare handed. For monkey bars in the TM, I'd suggest taking these off. I did and got right across. For going over the walls and up the quarter pipe, these things rule. I've also used them for minor construction projects and they are pretty good, protecting my hands and reducing vibrations from sanders and the like. One odd thing though, for me, the thumb fits a bit odd. I've had two pairs of these, one large, one medium, and the area between the index finger and the thumb feels short and tight, as if made for people with really short thumbs. Strange, but not necessarily uncomfortable, and will stretch out it seems after a while. People with super large hands will want the Large/X-large size.Pros: EXCELLENT grip when dry. GREAT fingertip protection. Good knuckle protection. Light and responsive. They also drain pretty well if you open and close tight fists, the water comes right out. Really inexpensive. Decent grip with organic material (ropes, wood, etc) when wet.Cons: Can be hard to take off when wet. Slippery with metallic objects when wet. Grip surface can wear out pretty fast.Bottom line: These are really good gloves and you can't beat the price.

reviewText: I bought a fleet of Eheim Heaters, 25w, 50w, 100w, 125w, 150 watt, all for different size tanks as I renew my interest in aquatic life.  They all seemed ok, until this one decided to shift tank temps from 78 F to 94 F !  Not too good, but I believe that once in a while you need to fuss to find the sweet spot on these things, so I turn it down a few clicks to get it back to the 78 F range.  Keep in mind I'm an old timer and don't give a crap if the "dial number in blue" is accurate, no need for me to calibrate, once I find 78 degrees F I'm happy period, no need to fuss with a calibration ring.  Anyway, the heater just went ballistic a second time up to 96 F. I have three other tanks in the room with Eheim heaters, this one is not in the sun, they all are the same and the others are just fine so far, but now I feel like I have to watch them because this one is bad. It's a hospital tank, I have a $75. Aulnocara in treatment in it.  He didn't die, but I'm not happy going back to my Supreme heaters from 30 years ago to keep the tank stable, when I just bought a half dozen new Eheims.  I'll call customer service, it is less than 6 mos. old.  I'll update this review.  I hope they stand behind their product without a song and dance here.
summary: Not too good, but I believe that once in a while ...

reviewText: This is my second, the first is still working.  I gave it to my daughter so I could get the stainless steel model.  I cook on it two our of three evenings. Wow! What can I say about this thing? I truly enjoy cutting my grass. I don't have to maintain gasoline in my garage for a heavily polluting mower, my grass looks like it's been cut by scissors, and it's quiet. As long as you don't let you grass get heavily stalked, this thing chews through the job.Update:I've had this mower for a couple of months in an extremely patchy lawn.  Overall, I'm still pleased with it, but it has a few catches.1. Adjusting the blades seems to work best for me when I don't loosen the screws holding it all in place.  Just turning the adjusting screws works best for me.2. The springtime stalks that shoot up quickly from my grass are hard/impossible for this mower to deal with unless they're kept short.3. This mower does not deal with debris well, as mentioned in the manual.  I have hit some utility marker flag bits left behind and it sounds painful for the mower and causes some gouging of the blade.That said, here are its great qualities:1. My shoes don't turn green.  Seriously, the cut of this thing is like a pair of scissors.  It's supposed to be the fastest healing for the grass, and doesn't cause so much browning.2. It's quiet.  I've cut grass at 6AM without upsetting the neighbors.3. No pollution.  Seriously.  Lawnmower engines have tended to pollute more in an hour than your car driving 600 miles.  This thing only requires the energy you put into it.4. It's not that hard to mow.  I think a non-self-propelled rotary mower is probably about as difficult as this thing to push around.

We bought a 16ft Intex Ultraframe last year and spent the entire summer rinsing and replacing cartridge filters and generally accepting a cloudy, sediment-y pool. Our well water is fairly hard and has enough iron to color the water. We used an iron out product and plenty of chlorine products but felt that the filter was our weak link. So this year we decided to upgrade (from 1200 gpm cartridge to 1600 gpm sand filter) and after only running it for a couple of days we are amazed at the pump power and clarity of the water.The setup was quite simple, we used the inlet and outlet mounts from the original pump (as they were identical) so we didn't have to lower the pool level. Basically filling the kettle with sand and fastening all the piping and control valve. Backwashed and rinsed new sand as per directions and started filtering within 10 minutes.After running for about 6 hours we needed to backwash (pressure gauge shows when it is needed) as our pool water was new and we had iron sediment to clean out from our Sequa-Sol treatment. Started to backwash and could not believe the "ick" that came out from the filter. Once it ran clear, we switched off and back to regular filter. The discharge power was back as strong as could be.This filter is amazing. Any doubts/concerns that we had about the expense being worth it are GONE. Cartridges are $5 a pop and we'd be lucky to get a week out of one, plus the original filter/pump was not keeping up anyway. This unit will pay for itself in only one summer and our water will finally be crystal clear.
these replacement brushes are getting hard to find mine seem to last about a summer then need to be replaced .

You get what you pay for. Well worth the investment.We love this furniture. It looks about as realistic as it possibly can and feels great to the touch. I was tired of buying a disposable grill every three or four years and I was tired of running out of propane in the middle of the burn. So I went hunting for the best all-stainless natural gas portable out there, and I think I found it. For starters, the parent company, Onward Manufacturing, has been around about as long as me and has grown and morphed into one of the major contenders. They make and distribute other brands including Weber, but the Imperial line is the hands-down winner based an cost and features. And they're made in America.Everything except the cart box is solid stainless, including the double layer hood, the burners, reflectors and grates. It comes partially knocked down but is easily assembled with a #3 philips in about an hour. The instructions are all pictographic, so you don't need a degree in engineering to understand them. It comes complete with a back burner and rotisserie (both easily removed), three large drawers and even interior lights. The natural gas flex line and connections fittings are also included. I really don't think you'll find such a complete package until you approach the $2,000 range.My first few uses have been modest in scope, but the performance seems fine. There's a little front/back heat difference, but that's pretty common. The heat retention with the hood closed is impressive. The rotiserie roasts low and slow as you'd hope. Two large chickens took about an hour and were eavenly done.The $50 cover is worth the price, custom fit and heavy duty.

reviewText: The other reviewers are right on here. Battery life is terrible (6 hours to charge 20 minutes to run out). Also you'll need decent speakers. Our Itouch and it's small 3" portable speakers aren't enough to hear the music well with people talking and milling about in the yard. That said, it's much more expensive to go with a wooden box (at least the 5' size I got...somewhere around 400-500 bucks).Customer service was VERY GOOD to me.  I had ordered 2 of these boxes and one of them had some hidden damage from shipping.  I took a photo of the hidden damage and sent it to Architectural Depot, the reseller for this Mayne product.  They actually had a real person respond to me over email (after an initial boilerplate response) and immediately said they'd be shipping out a replacement, get this, withOUT requiring me to send back the damaged one FIRST.That's good customer service and it turned my 3.5 star review into a 4.5-5 star review (can't do half's on Amazon).All in all, I will buy these again for some other windows in the future - they do look good once installed.

Attention to detail is required.  Read the directions.  Timing and placement is everything.  Stink bugs are not good flyers and need an easy way to climb up onto the green fins on the bottom.  Don't expect them to fly onto them.  Make sure that at least one of the fins touches a tree branch or large surface.  I have mine in an Empress Tree that is loaded with the bugs, and in a week I catch about 15 to 20 bugs per trap.  I plan on moving the traps, as the directions recommend, closer to the house in a few weeks and then eventually in the attic for the winter.I also made a trap using a Pepsi bottle and used "Rescue" attractant and it works, but not near as good.
summary: Each trap good for 15 to 20 bugs a week.

reviewText: My 24 year old son used this the first couple times before I had a chance to get at it.  He said the electric start didn't work.  When I had my chance, I grabbed the instructions and walked through the starting procedure step-by-step. Once I found the rotary choke knob and set it, the electric start worked flawlessly.  No problems since.  We have only had 2-3 inches of snow at a time so far, so I can't speak to how it operates in the heavy stuff.  It has worked well in what we have had to this point.

i actually got this kit from Costco so i cant comment on delivery or price.  well i opened the box and everything was packed well which is good because solar panels are notoriously brittle.After assembling the support stand i realized that it is very flimsy and would most likely fall apart when i am trying to mount it onto the roof and the screw holes were wider than the rafters on my roof.  i also noticed the lower support wasnt high enough to properly support the panels.  i wound up welding some extra bands of steel to remedy this as well as welding the lower support on in the proper location.well after installing the panels on the roof facing west it was already generating power even though the panels were facing away from the setting sun.  now on to the charge controller and inverter.  the charge controller is adequate but i wish it had a volt meter so i would know hen to turn off the system when the battery is running low.  the battery connection on the charge controller is kind of small and the other accessories all connect to the battery so it would be best to build some sort of battery box with separate terminals for all the electrical connection.my opinion: the system is decent but i would suggest if you buy it that you should add to it

I did not purchase this mower from Amazon. I purchased it locally from one of the big box stores. Lacking mechanical prowess, I have not determined whether I tripped the fuse by entangling a piece of plastic in the blade, or the charge ran out. Either way, I cut my postage stamp sized urban lawn, hit the plastic, and the mower refused to restart. If you search "other " websites for reviews, you will see some have issues with the key fuse preventing continued (safe) operation or issues with a short battery life. I have two other mowers and have discovered the usefulness of starting fluid and fuel stabilizer.I will be returning to gas mowers, but will keep this monster. If you do not use the self propelled feature, be prepared for a mini workout. The mower has a little heft.Would I buy it again? Probably not considering the price and the size of my lawn.Does it work? Yes, but be advised the manual discourages using this mower to vertically mow slopes (my best falls occurred from this act)or mow wet grass.Some other reviewers mentioned buying another spare battery to prolong operation. I have been looking for some sort of planter you could hang on a wall as my cats will eat any plants they can get to. I stumbled across Wooly Pockets and decided to give them a try. I have had them about 3 weeks now and they are well made. I bought the mini which I was able to put 2 small plants into. I think once the plants grow larger and cover up the pocket they will look great. If you purchase these, make sure you follow the set up instructions carefully. You are supposed to soak the root ball of the plant in water before putting in the wooly pocket; I missed this step and just poured some water inside, and then the water started dripping thru the fabric in the front. If you follow the watering directions correctly, they do not leak. I like the fact that they are made in USA using recycled water bottles as well. Thanks Wooly!10/29/12 UPDATE: I have had this product a few months now and I feel like I can review it more accurately now. I really wanted to like this product, but I just haven't had very good luck with it. Initially I watered like the directions stated; about 1x per week. It is hard to water these properly; I realize you are to keep the water to the back side or tongue, but still it either rolls over the top of the soil or leaks thru the fabric easily if you give it a little too much. I thought my home was too dry as the water rolled over the soil so I tried to water a little more frequently but sill no luck. The first set of plants died in each of these; now I replaced one but the other one is hanging on my wall with dead plant leaves in it. I think part of the problem is that I bought the mini size; I think it is just too small for the plant to grow and be watered in properly. Also I wish the front of the pocket was lined as well to avoid and water leakage. Sorry, wooly wish I had a better review.

Being from the wilds of Pennsylvania, we don't grow much sorghum (if any) in our state. I first saw this last year at a fall festival where it had been cut and shocked for decoration, and asked the vendor what it was and she told me. I was hooked and then ordered the seeds through Amazon.I wasn't sure if I should sow them directly in the soil (we live near the woods and animals are constantly foraging) so started them inside mid-April. I planted in mid-May next to our house and they were a few inches tall. Of the 50 seeds I planted, however, only 17 germinated, that's the only reason I'm deducting one star.But all 17 plants grew.. and grew.. and grew. I am harvesting them now and the tallest is 14'. The sorghum has become quite the topic of conversation, too.  As the vendor did, I shocked it around our lamp post and it is just spectacular. The grains have turned red (not quite as red in the picture-- we've had two frosts already so I wasn't sure how much longer I should leave it in the ground).I am definitely planting this next year, if for no other reason than it was just so much fun to watch grow; and the sound of the leaves rustling outside the living room window was very pleasant to hear on a summer's evening.
summary: Amazing results, everyone loves my sorghum

Do not wash with soap, just use a scraper and scrape the remains off. If you are a Big Green Egg owner (congrats for owning the best bbq/grill/smoker/oven/etc in the world!) As you may know it is best just to place your stones back in the hot egg and let them cool with the egg, the high heat will clean the stones as well. I will buy more of these so I can cook 4 on my large egg along with the others on the XL. Again, just buy them, they are ridiculously cheap for what you get.

The times I contacted Joel he always answered very quickly, usually in just a few hours.The venus came with more than enough moss to fill the net pot and  I kept the extra incase I ever decided to buy a bare root plant.  My plant didn't like the journey to my cold mailbox and while it arrived green it wasn't long before many of the traps turned brown. Joel assured me this was normal due to the cold, but if it died to let him know. 4 months later and my plant is BOOMING! It never has less than 6 traps and constantly has new ones shooting up! reviewText: Purchased my first one 2 years ago for (I think) ~$700.  It worked for a month and quit.  Fortunately for me I bought it locally and the dealer took it back and gave me a new one.  That one worked for almost 2 years or really 8 months of frequent usage (Ohio swim season) and then the Drive stopped working.  A different local dealer got me a quote to repair (required sending back to Aquabot) for a new Drive motor for over $400.I see where I can buy a new one from Amazon for mid $500's and get a new one year warranty (or two if I use my credit card).  I have considered buying other robots, but the ones that seem to work well like this and possibly have a longer warranty are over $1000 and I just don't want to spend another $1000+ for some other robot, when I read many of them fail after a year or two.  Just because it has a longer warranty doesn't mean it won't break.  So I will probably buy another Aquobot Xtreme and keep the first one for spare parts.Part of the problem for repairs or warranty is you have to ship these things that weigh 30+ lbs in a big box at your expense, which just adds to the pain level.Only because I am familiar with this one and liked it's performance (when it worked), I think I will get another one and keep my costs down (for now, until it breaks).  It's a crap shoot, but at least it is made in America.

reviewText: This really did the job as a gift for my son-in-law---- he needed something to trim about 50 feet of tall bushes--- this did the job nicely and will serve him in the future.

I have an approx. 50'x150' lot with house in center. The normal assortment of suburban trees, bushes, a swing set, raised garden, and detached garage. If I were reviewing the quality of yard I would give it a 2.5 out of 5. It is uneven, has 4-6 varieties of grasses and weeds each equally making up an equal percentage of the lawn. It has a small hill as well. Not the perfect set up for a push reel mower but certainly a perfect test for one.Set up was easy and it took me about 15 minutes. 11mm and 18mm socket are the only two tools needed. You build the handle and attach the small rear wheels and away you go. Mower itself is heavy, in a good way. Handle has several adjustment points and it worked well for me at 6'3" at the longest setting. The mower pushes easily. The blades on mine at least were perfectly adjusted out of the box. In addition to the paper instructions included, there is a video I saw on the Fiskars site showing you how to adjust the blades if needed. Unit seems to be very robust and of a good quality.I set mine to cut fairly high as the grass was longer and I didn't want to leave a trail of long cut grass to rake up. The mower worked very well with grass and weeds with-in a inch or so of the height setting. Stuff that was a bit longer, like dandelion flower shoots or long wispy grass it tended to miss some. Not so much of the grass but more so the dandelion shoots. Overall though it did quite well on all parts of the lawn. The nicer parts of the lawn with the thickest and nicest grass, it did the best on. My neighbor actually came over and looked at it when I was out and commented that it seemed to be doing a very nice job as well.It doesn't cut with the same width as my gas mower and it took my a couple of passes to get the set up right so I wasn't missing a small strip between rows. It also doesn't cut when you aren't push forward so areas under things where you can kind of stick a gas mower and move it around, were a bit harder to deal with. Ditto for going around trees as I found a straight forward motion worked best and going in a circle was possible, just a bit harder to maintain the blade spin. I will just need to weed whip a little more of the yard when using the reel mower. I also never had any problem with it getting an obstruction that stopped it at all, despite my lawn having a some twigs and sticks. That might have been to to the height setting, but I could every so often hear something getting crunched and the mower blades kept on spinning.It is very quiet and less messy then a gas mower. I wore a pair of flip flops and my legs were very clean afterwards and the shoes didn't pick up any green staining like you would see after using a gas mower. Same workout to push around as the gas mower I have (non assisted type) but that isn't a bad thing as I enjoy the exercise. Having done the lawn once now, it did come out looking good overall even if it left some of the dandelion stalks. I do think I will be more prone to grabbing it on short notice and pushing it around to stay on top of things vs. the gas mower just because it is so simple and quiet. It won't replace my gas mower for 100% of my mowings, but it will be doing the vast majority of them going forward. Overall very happy to have it and would recommend it.Update: Have used it three times now without using the gas mower in between. It is doing a great job. Was able to get out this morning at 0730 and get the yard done without worrying about waking the neighbors. Can also talk to my daughter who likes to walk along side me.
summary: Quiet, easy to push, and works well

reviewText: No program disk is included and you are instructed to download the software from their website. So much for an easy setup. You will have to give them all your personal information in registrating the product before they will send you the software via e-mail. You will have to find UPC codes and serial numbers as well. After you install new batteries in the floating sensor and plug the reciever, you will be instructed to wait for the "signal bar" to register full strength. Unfortunatly, I only recieved a signal strength of 68% while holding the sensor near the reciever. Once I put the sensor in the pool less than 15 feet away, I was now getting a signal strength of 53%. It was now transmitting the pool temp, ORP, and PH. There was no chlorine reading, just a blank line. Everything else looked right, but it would now require a 4 hour "stabilization process". The process lasted for two hours and then lost the signal from the sensor and it was in a state of permanent limbo. It's pretty obvious this thing has a poor transmitter with little or no range. I never did get a chlorine reading and I wasted a whole Sunday on this stupid thing. The toll free customer assistance is Monday thru Friday 9am to 5pm. I'll be at work during those times, so that's not helpful at all. There are plenty of calibration settings were you can reset the radio transmission and recalibrate each reading, but it warns you it is only for "advanced users".The idea of this product is very neat, but obviously it's more trouble than it's worth. The final product was poorly tested and some of the working components are not reliable. I wish these companies would realize that consumers want products that work right out of the box. It's just taking up space in my pool and doing nothing.
summary: Don't waste your money! This thing doesn't work!

These arrived in good time and were packed well.  I recently had been seeing a lot of large roaches (water bugs, palmetto bugs, giant cockroaches, whatever they are) in my kitchen, and sometimes my bathroom.  They scare me to death even though I am a lot bigger than they are so I don't want to get too close to them, and I prefer not to use poisons - especially in the kitchen - because of my cats.The Roach Motels worked very well and are so easy to use.  Unlike ordinary cockroaches, the larger bugs are heavy enough that they fall down (but they then stick on the new bottom) when I turn the trap over.  I have read that some cockroaches have evolved so that now there are some which are no longer attracted by the Roach Motels' sweet odor, but luckily, not in my apartment.  It has now been a few weeks since I've seen a roach.  Yay!!

I have several bird feeders (suet, thistle, seed, etc.) in my yard here in Connecticut and I get a tremendous number and variety of birds. I always feel a bit guilty though that I don't pay enough attention to their water needs and it can get hot and dry here by July. I have a bird bath, but I'm not great at keeping it filled. For those reasons, this little water cooler for birds really appealed to me.I have to say I'm more than pleased with the quality and the design. First, it's very rugged and I don't think that, even if it fell from the hook where I have it hanging, that it would get hurt. Also, its very simple to use--just unscrew the base, fill it with water, re-attach the base and (quickly) flip it right-side up and you're ready to go. It's that easy. And the threads are very strong and the dish part screws on very securely.The loop at the top of the bottle makes it easy to hang. I used one of those elongated s-hooks that are used to hang a hanging pot from a branch or whatever and it works perfectly. A piece of nylon fishing line would work fine, too.I really am very pleased with this and I think it will be a hit with the birds (I just put it out today, so still waiting for the first customers). I'm hanging it next to my screened porch to keep the cats entertained. It's nice to find an affordable product like this that does what it says it will do, is nicely made and serves a good purpose. A great gift for your bird-feeding friends, too. I'll post some photos once the birds belly up to the bar.By the way, a few reviewers have said that they have had it up for a while and no takers yet. I suggest posting a sign nearby, pointing to the waterer. (Kidding.) It takes a little while for birds to feel safe around anything new in your yard. They see it, they know it's there, they'll come. If you want to attract them faster, try letting a hose drip into a bucket nearby for a few hours a day for a few days--birds are extremely attracted to moving water. If they think water is in the area, they will investigate more.
summary: This is a great idea, I love it & so nicely made!

reviewText: Received this lovely hummingbird feeder last week, filled it with nectar and hung it in the yard near the red flowering plants that draw hummingbirds. The antique bottle design is beautiful when the sun shines through it, and is easily filled and with the nicely designed bottom where the birds should visit the little red flowers which are made of metal on a metal lid over a plastic container. It looks snug enough to keep bees and wasps from getting in. My only concern was if the metallic red paint on the flowers is bright enough to draw hummingbirds. And it is, after a mere 5 days in the garden, this morning we had our first customer at this beautiful feeder. I ran to get a camera to capture the promised video, but a dad-gone robin plunked down on the deck railing adjacent to the feeder and the hummingbird flitted off. Not giving up, though. Will be watching and maybe can catch these tiny little birds chowing down at the cobalt blue feeder that is so pretty in the sunlight.

As stated above, I live in North Central Wisconsin, with all the winter weather adventures that this entails.  This little guy is great for just about anything you're going to need it for.Now that I have an entire winter under my belt with the Snow Joe, I can honestly say that it performed well above what I ever expected from a plastic, electric unit.  We got some pretty impressive snows, last winter, up to 26 inches at a time of wet and heavy snow.  The fist time we got 12 inches, I expected to have to call my brother-in-law and have him lend me his gas unit.  But the Snow Joe handled it.  I had to take two passes to get the full 12 inches, taking about 6 inches, then backing up and getting it clean to the concrete.  But compared to a shovel, or a the hassle and cost of a two stage gas unit, it was great.  It even handled the packed and frozen stuff the city plow leaves in front of the curbside mailbox.  It's so light that if I need to reposition it, I just pick it up and carry it to the next place.  As far as cord issues, I find that this is really no more hassle than you have while vacuuming, and once you work out a system for your particular drive/sidewalk, it gets second nature.  I did store the unit in the house, since it was small enough.  I just put down a garbage bag, with an old towel on top, to catch the melt.  By the end of the 2012/2013 winter, the snow piles in our boulevard were to tall for me to see over, at 6'1" tall, and our mailbox was accessed through a little hole we'd dug into that snow bank.  The Snow Joe had thrown all of it there, including the heavy piles left by the plow.  I worked it well above what the designers meant it to do, I'm sure, but it handled it.  Other than an occasional scratch from the odd rock and a missing sticker, or two, it barely looks used.Recommended, whole-heartedly, by this Wisconsinite, who's happy to no longer have to break his back, shoveling.

If you search key words online, all you can see are closed up pictures of double or triple flowers with blur back ground. You will never find the picture of full plants in different angles . I also searched on Youtube, there are only videos playing sliding show of those closeup fake pictures, not one video show double or triple desert roses lively.Don't buy any this kind of seeds from anybody, doesn't matter it's online or in the stores, because when you finally find out it's not real, it's already months or year later, and you can not ask them for refund. And those thieves are counting on that.To the sellers, please upload a video to show me that you indeed have double to triple desert roses, thank you.
summary: Fake seed, there are not such kind of double or triple Desert Roses.

This thing is AWESOME!. I've been messing around with several different cold smoke generators and none of them really worked well. This thing works really super!  I wasted too much money and time on those other things.After following the directions to "season" the tube and burn off left over oil from manufacturing, I put a couple pounds of cheese in my Masterbuilt Electric smoker and the Tube Smoker in the bottom.  I filled the Tube Smoker half full of pellets and fired it up.I DID NOT use any heat from the smoker itself for this test.  In fact I never plugged it in. The cheese will melt at just over 100 deg (F).  I wanted to see how much heat the Tube Smoker would generate because I want to use it for cold smoking.  I have a larger barrel style smoker I normally use for cold smoking because the heat source is well away from the food to be smoked.  Trying it in this smaller unit was just a test.The pellets lasted about 2.5 hours (half full).  There was enough heat generated to cause the cheese to soften but not melt.  I didn't think to put a thermometer inside so I don't know the exact temp.If I were to use the Tube Smoker in a BBQ grill for example, I would make sure the food to be smoked was as low as possible and plenty of air flow.  It does generate too much heat for a small, closed in space for cold smoking.It would work great in a BBQ grill to add smoke to your food.  If you're cooking steak, burgers, chicken.  I like to throw a couple pieces of Tri Tip (tied together) on the rotisserie and add wood chips to the coals.  I plan  to use the Tube Smoker next time in the BBQ.This is a really wonderful product and for price and my needs, I prefer it over the A-MAZE-N Smoker.  That's the "maze" style, wood dust smoker.  Such a simple but useful idea.

I used to own a B&D; GH600 Grass Hog so I base my review of this trimmer in how it is better or worse than the GH600. This trimmer has more power and a better balance and feel. It is easier to switch from trimmer to edger than the GH600 and the telescoping shaft is nice. The GH600 had .065 line and I had hoped the .080 line on this trimmer would be much better and last longer. I am disappointed that it uses much more line than the GH600 did. If you let it hit the sidewalk or fence too much the spool will be empty before you know it. If you buy wound replacement spools they cost $ 7.50 each. I wind my own. 375 feet of high quality .080 line cost me $ 14.75. The GH600 had a wire guide to use when edging, this has a wheel. I don't like the wheel because if you don't watch it you'll be rolling the wheel right down the sidewalk with the line hitting the concrete all the way. The GH600 had a sturdy cord retention hook, this trimmer does not. The spool cap was easy to get off on the GH600, it is more difficult on this trimmer, to the point that I use a small screwdriver to push in on each side to release it. I don't totally dislike it but had hoped a newer design trimmer would be an overall improvement.After using it now for a few weeks I have to say I am really unhappy with it now. It uses too much line. I cannot recommend this trimmer. Wasted my money.
summary: An Honest Comparison -  Old Trimmer Was Better Than This One

He said that his 2 Honda-engine based pressure washers don't have the pressure of the Subaru, don't hold up to long hours of pressure washing and they aren't built nearly as well. I took his word for it and I'm glad I did.It starts easy. It is easy to fuel. It is easy to operate. It is extremely well built. It is well designed, easy to wheel around... you name it, this pressure washer does everything right.The Powerstroke pressure washer with the Subaru Engine is simply awesome.  Maybe TOO good. From my perspective at this point, I just add gas and get out of her way - the Pressure Washer does the rest. She loves it. I love it. I HIGHLY recommend it.

I was worried about purchasing these after I read some of the reviews, but figured I knew enough about plants and terra cotta to make them work :) First, I submerged the Plant Nanny in water and let it soak for an hour or so. Terra cotta absorbs a lot of water, and I figured if the stakes were already full of moisture when placed into the dirt, they would be less likely to pull in moisture from the bottles as quickly. Then, I gave my plants (I use these on tomato plants) a healthy watering - almost 2x as much as I normally would on a regular water - to really soak the soil. Then, I placed the Plant Nanny in the soil and attached the water bottle (I use the Smart Water bottles with the labels peeled off - they are pretty sleek-looking and unobtrusive, so they aren't super noticeable in my yard). Works perfectly! The bottle didn't release any water upon being placed in the Plant Nanny and has been (very) slowly releasing water in the days since. My tomatoes are the only plants not on drip irrigation and I was always forgetting to water them regularly. These have been a lifesaver!

This panel arrived safely packed.  Aluminum casing is very well made.  The MC4 connectors are very nice as well.I use a Tracer 4210 40 Amp MPPT charger (Renogy MPPT40CC).  On a UV 2 day, I get 34 V (12.2 Volts - 3 amps).  This was expected behavior.  When UV is 5, this panel puts out 36.7 V (12.4 Volts - 8.5 amps) 105 Watts!  Very nice.On a sunny 70 F degree day, I measured 98-106 F on the bottom of the panel.  This is with a 15 knot breeze and 2' of clearance under panel.  So plenty of cooling at my location (La Conner, WA, USA).I am using this with 6 golf cart batteries (660 Ah). They are configured as a 12 Volt house bank on a 45' trawler. reviewText: among other things this product is also used for rapid growth and it can be used to make your very own feminized seeds for your herb. This is not water soluble so you need to make a small mixture using 91% isopropyl alcohol then you can put your GA3 and iso alc mixture into a quart spray bottle or an industrial sprayer if you so desire. This product comes complete with instructions on how to use it and make a mixture, a measuring spoon and safety gloves. This is a very potent GA3 product. if using to make feminized seeds indoors i would recommend using a Paclobutrazol (bush load) product on the plant you intend to treat, this will keep your plant from growing out to tall and to lanky. GA3 will dramatically increase internode length and growth in treated branches/plants. it causes herb plants to hermaphrodite so be sure to only get it on the plant/branch you want treated
summary: great product great price fast shipping

Goal Zero is great a putting together comprehensive, easy to use solar solutions that actually work and this latest "Goal Zero 41022 Guide 10 Plus Solar Recharging Kit" is no exception.This is their smallest/lightest comprehensive kit thats great for hiking or camping or for an emergency bag.  Its primarily meant to help power or charge small mobile USB, AA or AAA devices like phones, small tablet computers, flashlights, radios etc and offers a great solution for those away from normal power sources beyond their devices battery life.It consists of:1) A Nomad 7 Solar panel.  This consists of two rigid 3.5 watt high efficiency solar panels in a sturdy folding ballistic nylon frame (kind of like a wallet but bigger) that contains the electronics and power connections along with a zippered mesh pouch on the back of one panel that can hold the rest of the kit and more.  The panel has a flap with a magnetic closure and several cord loops in various positions to allow you to hang or fasten the panel to something.2) The Gide 10 Plus Recharger.  This is a small plastic box that holds 4 NiMh Rechargeable AA batteries (included) (or 4 AAA batteries - not included) that can charge the batteries to accumulate and store the power from the solar panel, and then provide higher levels of consistent power to your USB devices.3) 4 AA Rechargeable 2300mah 1.2v NiMh Goal Zero branded batteries.  These have good capacity but as the instructions say to make sure to charge them every few months, they are likely not low self discharge (LSD) batteries like Sanyo Eneloops that can retain 75% of their charge after 3 years.4) An AAA adapter5) A 12v female cigarette lighter cable to allow the panel to directly power some 12 volt devicesEverything fits in the mesh compartment on the back of the solar panel and it forms a package about 7"x9"x1.5" and weighing about 1lb 11oz.  There's plenty of room left in the pouch for the USB cables of whatever devices you might want to charge/power with this kit, more batteries etc and you'll still likely end up under 2 pounds.So what's good about this kit?  First off, its a kit thats easy to use, well designed and constructed, and contains all the bits an pieces you'll need (other than the USB cables specific to your devices).  As the panel is small and sunlight varies in strength the panel itself won't always consistently charge or power devices directly - so a power pack is included to accumulate/normalize/amplify that power and also make it available to USB devices when the sun isn't out.  And it doubles as a battery charger for AA or AAA batteries (although you have to charge 4 at a time).This is one of my favorite kits and I give it 4 stars.  Why only 4?  Well it is a bit bigger and heavier than it needs to be (see the PowerFilm AA and AA+USB units if you want the ultimate in tiny and light - but they are not as versatile).  The battery pack doesn't independently charge each battery but requires a set of 4 to charge anything.  The particular panel technology used is the most efficient in strong sunlight but in less ideal conditions it looses efficiency quickly (the PowerFilm panels are not as efficient in full sunlight but are much more efficient in less ideal conditions).I highly recommend this kit for an individual thats going to be "off grid" for a while that wants to continue to use a few small USB or AA or AAA devices.  If you have a lot of devices or want to power things for more than one person you might want to consider a bigger kit like the Sherpa 50.
summary: Great for Hiking, Camping and Emergency use of small USB or AA or AAA powered devices

I bought this to replace a Troy-bilt Trimmer purchased at Lowes. VM Innovations had good pricing, and it was shipped very fast. It seems well built and sturdy. It started right up. It is lightweight, easy to handle, and uses very little fuel. The trimmer head comes with line thicker than most trimmers, it doesn go through as much as my past trimmer. I have several fences to trim against, including chain link. My old trim head went through a significant amount of line, this head is much more economical. The safety guard for the trimmer covers the line well but does not get n the way of trimming. The extra attachments I have for my Troy Bilt (Hedge trimmer, edger, Chainsaw) also fit on this trimmer, which is a plus. The only negative about the product I would say is that when new it doesn't seem to hold an idle really well. You have to keep on the throttle a bit to keep it running. That seems to be going away as it gets broken in.Over, this is a great trimmer to use around the yard, and a great value. Would definitiley buy from VM innovations again.

It works as described, but it took a bit of experimenting to to get the adapter sock to stay on the blower. It is a clever design, and it does work with my very powerful Toro electric leaf blower as I describe below.I use it with an electric Toro blower. The blower is powerful enough to blow the adapter sock off the tapered blower attachment. After some experimenting I found the trick to make the connection very secure. 1) Slide the sock directly over blower port (with fan guard off, and buckle unthreaded). 2) Replace the fan guard over the sock, and 3) thread the rubber strap of the sock through the guard and tighten to secure it.The whole set up is very secure. I can hold the blower pipe with both hands with the Toro hanging off the bottom to blast the leaves and junk out of the gutters. The Toro-Worx combination does blast everything out of the gutter, esp. after the second pass. Once I figured out how to use it it got my gutters all blown out in just a few minutes. Much, much easier than running up and down a ladder.The piping is a bit flimsy. But that also makes it very light weight, so it is easy to get it up to your gutters, and to work with it without undo strain. The sock adapter seems to be quite robust, but the button holding it to the pipe could be stronger.Remember to wear a hat and eye protection. Lots of stuff comes raining down on you.
